## PHYSICS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 388, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[750, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[55, 31, 413, 67]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 126, 87]]<|/det|> Data <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 100, 692, 530]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall\(g\) = 9.81 m s⁻²
speed of light in free space\(c\) = 3.00 x 10⁸ m s⁻¹
elementary charge\(e\) = 1.60 x 10⁻¹⁹ C
unified atomic mass unit1 u = 1.66 x 10⁻²⁷ kg
rest mass of proton\(m_p\) = 1.67 x 10⁻²⁷ kg
rest mass of electron\(m_e\) = 9.11 x 10⁻³¹ kg
Avogadro constant\(N_A\) = 6.02 x 10²³ mol⁻¹
molar gas constant\(R\) = 8.31 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹
Boltzmann constant\(k\) = 1.38 x 10⁻²³ J K⁻¹
gravitational constant\(G\) = 6.67 x 10⁻¹¹ N m² kg⁻²
permittivity of free space\(\varepsilon_0\) = 8.85 x 10⁻¹² F m⁻¹
Planck constant\(h\) = 6.63 x 10⁻³⁴ J s
Stefan–Boltzmann constant\(\sigma\) = 5.67 x 10⁻⁸ W m⁻² K⁻⁴
<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 565, 171, 580]]<|/det|> Formulae <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 594, 615, 850]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion\(s\) = \(ut + \frac{1}{2} at^2\)
\(v^2\) = \(u^2 + 2as\)
hydrostatic pressure\(\Delta p\) = \(\rho g \Delta h\)
upthrust\(F\) = \(\rho g V\)
Doppler effect for sound waves\(f_0\) = \(\frac{f_s V}{V \pm V_s}\)
electric current\(I\) = \(Anvq\)
resistors in series\(R\) = \(R_1 + R_2 + ...\)
resistors in parallel\(\frac{1}{R}\) = \(\frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_2} + ...\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 70, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 71, 149, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 71, 284, 88]]<|/det|>
Define velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 165, 149, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 165, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
In an experiment, two objects A and B are released from the side of a building, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 206, 784, 484]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 503, 590, 520]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 534, 781, 551]]<|/det|>
Object A is released from rest at a height of 10.0 m above horizontal ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 549, 920, 597]]<|/det|>
Object B is released with an initial upward velocity of \(3.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at a height \(h\) above the ground. Both objects take the same time to reach the ground and they do not collide with each other. Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 612, 257, 628]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 764, 920, 781]]<|/det|>
<form>h = .................................................................... m [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
In a second experiment, object B is released from the same height as in (b) but with a speed of \(6.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) to the vertical, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 116, 638, 230]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 294, 533, 312]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 325, 180, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 325, 917, 359]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the time taken for object B to reach the ground is less than, the same as, or greater than the time taken in the first experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 432, 918, 450]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 463, 181, 482]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 463, 918, 498]]<|/det|>
By considering energy, state and explain whether the speed at which object B reaches the ground is less than, the same as, or greater than in the first experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 603, 918, 621]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 513, 90]]<|/det|>
Define the moment of a force about a pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 134, 917, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 148, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 918, 199]]<|/det|>
Three objects A, B and C are placed on a horizontal beam. The beam is in equilibrium, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 208, 801, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 400, 590, 418]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 432, 505, 450]]<|/det|>
The beam is uniform and has length 9.0m.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 448, 470, 464]]<|/det|>
A pivot is at the midpoint of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 463, 615, 479]]<|/det|>
Object A has mass \(90\mathrm{kg}\) and is at one end of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 478, 670, 494]]<|/det|>
Object B has mass \(m\) and is a distance of \(3.0 \text{m}\) from the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 492, 670, 509]]<|/det|>
Object C has mass \(150\mathrm{kg}\) and is at the other end of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 524, 185, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 524, 301, 542]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 725, 918, 742]]<|/det|>
<form>m = .................................................................... $kg$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 725, 918, 743]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 72, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
Object A is removed and replaced by a wire fixed to the end of the beam and to the ground, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 116, 866, 256]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 2.2 </center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 300, 920, 333]]<|/det|>
After the change, the beam is again horizontal and in equilibrium. The positions of B and C are unchanged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 348, 772, 381]]<|/det|>
The wire has a diameter of \(1.8 \times 10^{- 3} \text{m}\) and has a strain of \(1.2 \times 10^{- 3}\). The wire is not extended beyond its limit of proportionality.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 394, 533, 411]]<|/det|>
Calculate the Young modulus of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 580, 920, 598]]<|/det|>
<form>Young modulus = ............................................................ Pa [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 612, 180, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 612, 918, 645]]<|/det|>
Object B is now moved to a new position closer to the pivot without passing it. The beam is again horizontal and in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 660, 785, 677]]<|/det|>
State and explain the effect, if any, that this has on the strain in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 783, 920, 801]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
A car of mass \(1500\mathrm{kg}\) is travelling along a straight horizontal road at constant velocity \(v\). The car is subject to a total resistive force \(F\), as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[171, 116, 826, 275]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 3.1</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 325, 146, 343]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 325, 918, 357]]<|/det|>
Show that the power \(P\) developed by the engine in overcoming the total resistive force is given by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 369, 534, 386]]<|/det|>
\[P = Fv.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 540, 920, 559]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 571, 148, 590]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 571, 675, 590]]<|/det|>
The car now moves up a slope at a constant speed of \(30 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 587, 732, 604]]<|/det|>
The slope is at an angle to the horizontal of \(6.0^{\circ}\) , as shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 616, 833, 737]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 753, 534, 771]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 3.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 785, 580, 803]]<|/det|>
The total resistive force acting on the car is 1600N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
Show that the increase in gravitational potential energy of the car in a time of 1.0s is 46 000 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 228, 920, 246]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 259, 181, 276]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 259, 918, 293]]<|/det|>
Use the information in (b)(i) to determine the power developed by the engine to move the car up the slope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[514, 427, 918, 445]]<|/det|>
<form>power = ............................................................ W [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 460, 146, 478]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 460, 905, 478]]<|/det|>
The car picks up a passenger and then continues up the slope at the same speed as in (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 490, 667, 508]]<|/det|>
State and explain the effect, if any, that the passenger has on:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 522, 180, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 522, 482, 540]]<|/det|>
the air resistance acting on the car

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 583, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 615, 181, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 615, 492, 632]]<|/det|>
the power developed by the engine.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 706, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 706, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 72, 561, 90]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 196, 918, 244]]<|/det|>
An object A of mass \(4.0\mathrm{kg}\) travels at a velocity of \(6.0\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) to the right on a horizontal frictionless surface. It moves towards a second object B of mass \(2.0\mathrm{kg}\) that is moving at a velocity of \(3.0\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) in the same direction as A, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 255, 312, 273]]<|/det|>
object A, mass \(4.0kg\)

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 255, 885, 368]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[472, 787, 918, 805]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 72, 531, 90]]<|/det|>
State why sound waves cannot be polarised.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 135, 910, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 148, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 818, 183]]<|/det|>
A plane-polarised light wave is incident on a polarising filter as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 191, 819, 325]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 339, 532, 357]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 370, 565, 388]]<|/det|>
The intensity of the light incident on the filter is \(I_{0}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 401, 918, 434]]<|/det|>
The light is incident normally on the filter and the transmission axis of the filter is initially perpendicular to the plane of polarisation of the light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 447, 835, 464]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 478, 181, 496]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 478, 918, 510]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 718, 532, 736]]<|/det|>

<mark>[3]

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 104, 918, 136]]<|/det|>

<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 151, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 72, 437, 90]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by diffraction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 165, 149, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 918, 199]]<|/det|>
Light of wavelength \(720 \text{nm}\) in a vacuum is incident normally on a diffraction grating as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[70, 208, 925, 560]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 572, 590, 590]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 6.1 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 604, 918, 637]]<|/det|>
A screen is parallel to the grating. An interference pattern is seen on the screen and the angle between the second-order maxima is \(52^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 650, 181, 668]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 650, 487, 667]]<|/det|>
Calculate the frequency of the light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 772, 920, 790]]<|/det|>
<form>frequency = ............................................................ $Hz$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 772, 920, 790]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 73, 176, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 761, 90]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 304, 918, 321]]<|/det|>
<form>number per unit length = .................................................... $\text{m}^{-1}$ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 335, 180, 354]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 918, 382]]<|/det|>
The light in Fig. 6.1 is now replaced with light of a different wavelength \(\lambda\). It is observed that the third-order maxima of this light are at the same positions as the second-order maxima of the light in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 397, 484, 413]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 581, 918, 598]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 613, 918, 630]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
A nichrome resistance wire has length \(150 \text{cm}\), cross-sectional area \(2.45 \times 10^{-7} \text{m}^2\) and resistivity \(1.12 \times 10^{-6} \Omega \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 120, 146, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 119, 678, 136]]<|/det|>
Calculate, to three significant figures, the resistance of the wire.
